awd_titl_txt: Systemic Transformation of Inquiry Learning Environments for STEM (STILE 2.0)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The project at The Center for Technology and School Change (CTSC) at Teachers College, Columbia University, is a four-year, early-stage design and development project aimed to refine a state-of-the-art professional development model to prepare K-8 teachers and instructional leaders in urban schools to facilitate and support successful K-8 STEM Education. This project will explore the most effective features for preparing teachers to design and implement authentic STEM learning experiences in twelve high need elementary and middle urban schools across New York City and Yorkers. The project will specifically explore which components of the program promote teacher change, which aspects of the program support structural changes for STEM teaching in schools, and what holds promise for interdisciplinary STEM teacher development. 

Participants in this project will design and implement transdisciplinary STEM projects and learn to develop and support STEM learning environments for their schools. As part of this overall process, researchers will refine a situated professional development curriculum, including a suite of digital case studies that will assist schools.  The project will: 1) build a vision for trans-disciplinary STEM schooling; 2) design and implement STEM learning experiences; and 3) take capacity-building steps to sustain STEM practices. A mixed method design approach will be used to explore both the implementation of the project and the effect of implementation on participants.

por.por_cntn:
The Systemic Transformation of Inquiry Learning Environments (STILE) is a STEM application of the Innovating Instruction model, developed at the Center for Technology and School Change (CTSC), and representative of more than a decade of work with schools in the U.S. and abroad. The National Science Foundation support for the STILE project has provided research funding to study 169 teachers as they learned to develop and implement 4-6 week STEM project units. The work takes a transdisciplinary approach to STEM, which requires a focus on crosscutting concepts and big ideas that can transcend a siloed discipline approach and find application in local, real world settings. Teachers participated in up to 60 hours of professional learning, over a two-year initiative, consisting of up to three summer institutes, co-planning meetings with facilitators, project implementation support, and structured reflection. Facilitators also met with administrators to support the teachers' pedagogical growth and to discuss the organizational changes needed to support integrated STEM approaches in schools.  

Innovating Instruction was developed as a model for school change to help teachers and administrators learn the design skills needed to shift from transmission-directed teaching to inquiry-based teaching. The professional learning program that was designed to support this transition is focused on helping teachers acquire the vision and skills to design rigorous standards-aligned, culturally relevant projects that engage students in collaborative inquiry. The design process provides teachers with the knowledge, skills, and agency to create standards-aligned learning opportunities around students' strengths and needs. 

Numerous positive findings established a strong evidence base for CTSC's transformative Innovating Instruction model within the context of transdisciplinary STEM education. Specifically, teachers (1) learned to design robust and culturally relevant STEM projects, (2) deepened their understanding of STEM, and (3) sustained their beliefs/perspectives about STEM over time. Concurrent with teacher participation in the transdisciplinary STILE approach, teachers made statistically significant shifts from singular, disciplinary ideas about STEM to a more sophisticated transdisciplinary focus. Teachers also made measurably significant changes to their thoughts around and approaches to STEM design. These surveyed gains were sustained one year following the STILE experience. 

The project team believes these outcomes will have a notable impact on the field's understanding of STEM teaching and learning--namely, that teachers can deepen their understanding of STEM through a transdisciplinary, student-centered, culturally relevant STEM design process. Prioritizing support for teachers in this way has provided them with a meaningful process for creating more equitable opportunities for STEM learning. It is hoped that this work highlights the need to continue developing creative opportunities for teachers to learn to design rigorous, culturally sustaining projects that can engage students in authentic applications of STEM. 

The STILE work reported herein is preceded by an exploratory study (NSF-1238643) and followed by a late-stage research and development initiative (NSF-2010530). 

For more about this project, please visit: https://ctsc.tc.columbia.edu/ctsc/research/nsf-stile/
